LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of the Philippines 
   
The Proposal  A loan of $250 million is proposed for subprogram 3 of the Development 
Policy Support Program (DPSP). This is the third loan of a program cluster 
and  builds  on  support  initiated  under  subprogram  2,  approved  by  the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) in September 2008. The loan is to be 
provided  as  a  single  tranche,  based  on  completed  prior  actions 
demonstrating satisfactory progress.  
   
Classification  Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Sector (subsector): Public sector management (economic and public 
affairs management) 
Themes (subthemes): Economic growth (promoting macroeconomic 
stability), governance (public administration), private sector development 
(private sector investment) 
Location impact: National (low impact) 
Partnership: Government of Japan 
   
Environment  Category C       
Assessment 
   
The Program  The  Government's  implementation  of  its  Medium-Term  Philippine 
Rationale  Development Plan (MTPDP) is stimulating higher and more sustainable 
economic growth (7% per annum by 2009), creating jobs (1 million jobs 
created by 2009), and reducing poverty. Poverty rates have declined over 
the past 2 decades, but recently increased (to 33% of the population in 
2006 from 30% in 2003). The critical fiscal situation that emerged in 2002 
compressed public investment and funding for the social sectors and hurt 
the poor. These problems were compounded by poor governance in public 
financial management, corruption in procurement, and a weak investment 
climate.  
 
Reforms  supporting  fiscal  consolidation;  strengthening  governance  in 
public  financial  management;  reducing  corruption  in  key  government 
agencies; and improving the investment climate, rural development, and 
infrastructure are crucially important to putting economic growth on a more 
sustainable  path,  redirecting  spending  to  the  social  sectors,  and 
contributing to poverty reduction. The ADB studies, Philippines: Critical 
Development Constraints in 2007, and Philippines: Reforming Investment 
Incentives in 2009, confirmed that these areas are critical to growth in the 
Philippines and were used in formulating subprogram 3. 
 
Under subprogram 1, the Government implemented a series of measures 
to  address  the  fiscal  imbalance,  resulting  in  a  swift  and  impressive 
turnaround in the fiscal situation and greater macroeconomic stability in 
2006 and 2007. Subprogram 2 in 2008 built on reforms initiated under 
subprogram 1 on fiscal consolidation and governance in public financial 
management  and  procurement.  These  measures  have  provided  much 
needed  fiscal  space  for  greater  spending  on  the  social  sectors  and

ii 
 
infrastructure in 2007 and 2008. With higher spending for priority sectors, 
set  within  a  medium-term  balanced  budget  framework,  the  Philippines 
enjoyed  its  best  recent  macroeconomic  performance  in  2007  with 
economic growth at 7.2% and investment growth at 11.5%. This growth 
momentum continued into the first quarter of 2008.  
 
However, 2008 began with a surge in global commodity prices. By the 
third quarter, domestic food price inflation had reached 25% in the third 
quarter on a year-on-year basis and this contributed to a slowdown in 
domestic consumption and an increase in poverty. The global financial 
crisis  intensified  in  September  2008  and  adversely  affected  Philippine 
financial markets in two ways: (i) balance sheet deleveraging in the United 
States meant investors unbundled financial portfolios in the Philippines, 
leading to some capital flight in the second half of 2008; and (ii) the global 
credit crunch has made it more expensive for the Philippines to access 
international debt markets, in both public and private sectors.  
 
However, the major impact on the Philippine economy is the second-round 
effects of global demand decline and the impact on the Government's 
fiscal situation. Economic growth decelerated sharply in the first quarter of 
2009  following  a  40%  plunge  in  external  demand  for  exports  from 
December 2008 to April 2009 and lack of growth in inflows of remittances 
in  the  first  semester  of  2009.  The  Government  has  revised  its 
macroeconomic framework and projects growth at 0.8%–1.8% in 2009 
with higher unemployment. Development partners project a lower growth 
rate in the range of –1.0% to 1.0% on the back of faltering exports, stalling 
foreign investments, and a projected drop in remittances. These growth 
forecasts would translate to a decline in per capita incomes in the range of 
–3.0% to –0.2%, thereby threatening to raise poverty further in 2009.   
 
The Government has responded to the global crisis in two ways. First, it 
has introduced preemptive measures to support macroeconomic stability. 
Second, it has provided for a modest fiscal expansion in the order of 2.3% 
of gross domestic product (GDP) in 2009. The stimulus will come from 
higher infrastructure and social spending, and cash transfers to the poor. 
The sharp cyclical downturn in the economy has also affected the fiscal 
situation through a decline in tax revenues of 5.2% in the first semester of 
2009. As a result of the increase in spending and falling revenues, the 
Government revised its estimate of the national government deficit to 3.2% 
of GDP in 2009.  
 
Subprogram 3 builds on reforms initiated under subprogram 2 for fiscal 
consolidation  and  strengthening  of  governance  in  public  financial 
management  and  procurement.  It  also  increases  the  focus  on 
institutionalizing  governance  programs  within  agencies  to  ensure  their 
longer-term  sustainability  and  effective  enforcement,  strengthening  the 
investment  climate,  and  carrying  out  social  assistance  programs. 
Responding to the global financial crisis, subprogram 3 also includes a 
series of policy measures to address the increased vulnerabilities and 
risks to the Philippine economy from the global financial crisis and the 
impacts on poverty. These reforms are designed to: (i) improve fiscal

iii 
sustainability,  maintain  macroeconomic  stability,  and  improve 
creditworthiness; (ii) enhance governance in public financial management 
and speed up disbursements of critical public spending; (iii) improve the 
investment  climate  and  rural  development;  and 
(iv) enhance human capital and social inclusion.  
 
Also in response to the global economic crisis, subprogram 3 adds a post- 
program monitoring framework with forward-looking policy measures. The 
Government of the Philippines, ADB, and the Government of Japan have 
agreed to a post-DPSP framework with policy measures in order to create 
the  basis  for  continuous  policy  dialogue  and  engagement  during  the 
critical period of 2009–2010 before the Philippine presidential elections in 
May 2010. The monitoring framework focuses on the Government's short-
term  plan,  advancing  its  reforms  in  fiscal  policy,  public  financial 
management,  and  selected  areas  in  investment  climate  and  poverty, 
supported by ADB, the Government of Japan, and other development 
partners' technical and program assistance.   
 
The DPSP  is a joint effort of ADB, the Government of Japan (Japan 
International  Cooperation  Agency)  and  other  development  partners  to 
support and deepen a common reform agenda with the Government. It 
reflects the Government’s commitment to its reforms over the medium 
term, and ADB’s commitment over the medium term to provide financial 
support to program implementation. The Government of Japan provided 
parallel financing of subprogram 2 in March 2009 and will provide parallel 
financing for subprogram 3. In formulating the DPSP, the Government, 
ADB, and the Government of Japan have drawn on the Government’s 
agenda as articulated through the Philippines Development Forum and its 
sector strategies. ADB and the Government of Japan have coordinated 
reviews of subprogram 3 policy triggers with the Government. Formulation 
of subprogram 3 has benefited from input from the Australian Agency for 
International  Development  (AusAID),  United  States  Agency  for 
International Development (USAID), and the World Bank.  
   
Impact and  The impact of subprogram 3 will be to restore the Philippines to a longer-
Outcome  term, sustainable, and higher growth path and to lower unemployment. 
The outcome of the subprogram 3 will be more investment through greater 
fiscal sustainability, better public financial management, a more attractive 
investment climate, and enhanced human capital and social inclusion. To 
achieve these objectives, subprogram 3 will support the following strategic 
reforms:  
 
(i)  improvements  to  fiscal  sustainability,  maintenance  of 
macroeconomic  stability,  and  better  creditworthiness  by 
enhancing the quality of fiscal management by (a) increasing tax 
revenues  for  2008–2009  through  tax  policy  reforms, 
(b)  strengthening  tax  administration  and  enforcement,  and 
reducing  revenue  leaks  through  improved  governance, 
(c) reducing inefficient spending to permit increased social and 
poverty-related spending, (d) strengthening the debt management 
strategy  to  manage  government  contingent  liabilities  and  risks

iv 
 
prudently, and (e) giving depositors' confidence in the domestic 
banking system; 
(ii)  enhancements to public financial management  governance by 
(a) improving budget preparation, budget execution, accounting, 
recording,  and  reporting;  (b)  strengthening  performance 
management and improving public service delivery; (c) reforming 
procurement;  (d)  implementing  anticorruption  and  enforcement 
strategies for revenue-collecting agencies, and key procurement 
agencies;  and  (e)  sustaining  critical  public  expenditures  while 
maintaining budget discipline to mitigate the poverty impacts of 
the deceleration in growth; 
(iii)  improvements to the investment climate and promotion of rural 
development  by  (a)  clarifying  and  strengthening  the  legal  and 
regulatory  framework  for  investments  and  trade,  (b)  facilitating 
infrastructure  development  through  greater  public–private 
participation  and  better  coordination  of  public  infrastructure 
investments, and (c) improving rural–urban connectivity; and  
(iv)  enhancements to human capital and social inclusion by improving 
the  policy  framework  for  social  protection,  sustaining  real 
spending  on  health  and  education,  improving  the  targeting  of 
programs, piloting the conditional cash transfer (CCT) program 
tied  to  performance  outcomes  in  child  education  and  health, 
refining public employment programs, and establishing a national 
poverty  monitoring  and  response  system  to  help  mitigate  the 
impact of the economic slowdown on poverty. 
 
Financing Plan  A loan of $250,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources will be 
provided  under  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based 
lending  facility  for  subprogram  3  of  the  Development  Policy  Support 
Program. The loan will have a 15-year term including a grace period of 3 
years, an interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-based 
lending facility, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft 
program loan agreement.  
   
Period and  The subprogram 3 period is from October 2008 to September 2009, with a 
Tranching  single tranche loan of $250 million to be disbursed when the Government 
has met the conditions for loan effectiveness.  
   
Counterpart  The Government will use the local currency counterpart funds generated 
Funds  by the loan proceeds to meet program expenditures and associated costs 
of  reform,  and  to  help  maintain  current  social  expenditure  and 
infrastructure spending.

Program Benefits  The DPSP will provide the following significant benefits:  
and Beneficiaries    
(i)  progress  toward  medium-term  fiscal  sustainability  will  promote 
macroeconomic stability and foster broad-based economic growth, 
job creation, and poverty reduction, all of which are cornerstones of 
the Government’s MTPDP and the Philippines Development Forum 
(the  successful  fiscal  consolidation  programs  since  2004  have

(ii)  better  governance  of  public  financial  management  will  improve

(iii)  lower transaction costs for business, because of the reduction in

(iv)  higher  infrastructure  spending  will  generate  long-term  growth,

(v)  improved social sector outcomes will result from higher spending,

(vi)  key governance programs will be more sustainable, as the DPSP

Risks and  The  DPSP  is  firmly  embedded  in  the  MTPDP,  the  Philippines 
Assumptions  Development  Forum,  and  the  Government’s  ongoing  sector  strategies 
covering  its  fiscal  program,  tax  administration  reform,  public  financial 
management,  procurement  reform,  investment  competitiveness,  rural 
development,  and  social  protection.  The  assumptions  underlying  the 
DPSP include the following:

vi 
 
(i)  The economy will be able to continue withstand the direct effects of 
the global financial crisis on Philippine financial markets. 
(ii)  The Government will maintain fiscal expansion in 2009 and 2010 
within a disciplined fiscal framework. 
(iii)  The  Government  will  stay  on  course  with  key  policy  reform 
measures, and continue to liaise effectively with Congress.  
 
However, the DPSP has risks:  
 
(i)  The global financial crisis has hurt the Philippines. The second-round 
effects of the decline in global demand have had repercussions on 
the Government's fiscal situation in an environment of elevated risk 
and  higher  cost  of  financing.  A  prolonged  global  recession  and 
dysfunctional credit markets would place further stress on the fiscal 
situation as about $8.0 billion of public external debt matures in 2009 
and  2010.  The  economic  slowdown  in  the  Philippines  and  the 
possibility  that  remittances  may  decline  would  feed  into  higher 
poverty in 2009. However, these potential effects on poverty would 
be partially offset through the scaling up of the CCT and an increase 
in infrastructure development in 2009 and 2010. 
(ii)  With the economic stresses in 2009 and an election in 2010, the 
Government may be tempted to introduce populist policies that could 
threaten  fiscal  discipline  in  2010.  However,  the  Government  has 
announced that its budget target for 2010 is 2.5% of GDP and since 
2006 it has demonstrated commitment to meeting its fiscal targets. In 
2009, it is operating one of the lowest deficits in the region. The post-
program monitoring framework will enable ADB to continue dialogue 
with Government on fiscal policy. 
(iii)  The 2010 presidential elections may slow implementation of reforms. 
However, the Government has full ownership of the DPSP reform 
program, which is embedded in the Philippines Development Forum 
and  its  sector  strategies.  Moreover,  the  Government  of  the 
Philippines, ADB, and the Government of Japan have agreed to a 
post-program  monitoring  framework  with  triggers  to  track  the 
Government's commitment to its reform agenda.

Component 3 will support capacity development at the new debt and risk

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of the Philippines for subprogram 3 of the Development Policy Support Program 
(DPSP).1 The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Improving Public 
Financial  Management,  and  if  the  Board  approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the 
authority  delegated  to  me  by  the  Board,  will  approve  the  TA.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 
A.  The Global Crisis 
2.  The proposed DPSP subprogram 3 comes at a critical time for the Philippines. It is 
designed to maintain the momentum of its key development efforts at a time of global financial 
market failure and global recession. Like many other developing economies, the Philippines has 
had to cope with the first-round effects of the turmoil and the crisis of confidence that has 
disrupted  the  global  financial  system  and  limited  the  country's  access  to  commercial  debt 
markets since September 2008 (Appendix 4). Coming into the global crisis, the Philippines’ 
macroeconomic performance was sound. The economy expanded by 3.8% in 2008—half the 
7.3% in 2007, but above the regional average. The primary budget has been in surplus for the 
last 3 years and its overall deficit for 2008 was 0.9% of gross domestic product (GDP), low by 
international standards. The public debt–GDP ratio has continuously declined from over 80% in 
2003 to 56% by the end of 2008.   
 
3.  The Philippines is now experiencing the second-round effects of the global recession, 
which may be larger than those caused by the 1997–1998 Asian financial crisis. The economies 
of the Philippines’ major trading partners and recipients of Filipino workers have entered severe 
recessions. Global trade contracted by about 9% in the first quarter of 2009—the first time since 
1982. Consequently, Philippine exports (mainly influenced by the sharp contraction in exports of 
electronics) contracted by about 40% from December to April 2009 on a year-on-year basis. A 
consensus in the international community is that the global economy may only experience a 
gradual recovery in 2010 and this turnaround will depend critically on more concerted policy 
actions  to  stabilize  financial  conditions  and  bolster  demand  through  fiscal  expansion  and 
monetary policy. The Government has learned from the 1997–1998 financial crisis and its 2009 
budget included greater discretionary spending mainly on infrastructure, social sectors, and 
cash  transfers  to  the  poor.  As  a  result  of  these  spending  initiatives  and  lower  projected 
revenues, the 2009 budget deficit is projected to rise to 3.2% of GDP and the Government's net 
financing requirements will be about P270.6 billion. Despite policy makers' immediate focus on 
the current economic crisis, the Government also considers the crisis to be an opportunity to 
achieve consensus among stakeholders on difficult policy issues and to advance its medium-
term  development  objectives  in  fiscal  policy,  public  financial  management,  the  investment 
climate, and social sectors, recognizing that these reforms have helped the Philippines to 
weather this crisis and to position it for recovery.

B.  The Government and its Development Strategy 
4.  The  DPSP  program  cluster  supports  the  Government's  development  strategy  as 
described in its Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan, 2004–2010 (MTPDP), which sets 
out the country’s development priorities, policy agenda, programs, and projects. 2  The key 
objectives of the MTPDP are to achieve higher and more sustainable economic growth, create 
jobs, reduce poverty, and make progress toward the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). It 
identifies  the  major  challenges  as  the  fiscal  imbalance,  inadequate  infrastructure,  rapid 
urbanization  and  congestion  (especially  in  Metro  Manila),  increasing  unemployment,  and 
inefficient delivery of basic services. 
 
5.  In 2005, the Government and its international development partners decided to convert 
annual consultative group meetings into the Philippines Development Forum (PDF). The PDF 
provides an opportunity for ongoing dialogue and for involving other stakeholders, such as civil 
society, the private sector, and the academic community. The Government convenes the PDF 
to  discuss  the  reform  agenda  and  how  the  development  partners  can  assist  with 
implementation.3 The PDF allows the development partners to provide an impetus to MTPDP 
implementation. Currently the PDF has seven working groups,4 each focusing on priority areas 
of the Government’s development agenda. In March 2006, the Government agreed with the 
World Bank that the PDF agenda would be used as the basis for a World Bank development 
policy loan. Shortly thereafter, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) was invited to join the 
process and to prepare the reform agenda through the DPSP. The agenda was refined and 
modified through subsequent PDF workshops in 2007 and 2008 to reflect the Government’s 
new priorities, and its short- and medium-term challenges. When the DPSP was first formulated 
in 2006 (footnote 1], it was anchored on four core areas of the PDF: (i) fiscal consolidation, (ii) 
governance, (iii) the investment climate and infrastructure, and (iv) social progress. At the 
request of the Government in 2008, subprogram 3 of the DPSP added rural development to the 
investment climate component, reflecting the Government’s and ADB’s increased focus on 
improving the investment climate. 
 
6.  To  help  implement  the  MTPDP  priorities,  the  Government  adopted  several  sector 
strategies,  most  with  a  time-bound  implementation  plan  and  clearly  defined  ministerial 
responsibilities;  some  are  supported  by  ADB  sector  programs  and  technical  assistance 
(Appendix 9). The fiscal consolidation strategy, which began in 2004, outlined the Government’s

III.  THE SECTOR  
A.  Recent Economic Developments and the Impacts of the Global Financial Crisis 
12.  Resilient  macroeconomic  performance  in  2008.  Until  September  2008,  the 
Philippines was able to withstand the negative impacts of the global crisis because of the 
Government's sound macroeconomic and fiscal policy, a more resilient financial sector, and 
adequate levels of foreign reserves (Table 1). Economic growth was 3.8% above the regional 
average (Figure 1). The current balance of payments account recorded a respectable surplus of 
$4.2 billion (2.5% of GDP) for 2008, buoyed by record remittances of $16.4 billion. However, 
significant portfolio capital outflow in the third and fourth quarters of 2008 reduced the overall 
balance of payments position from a solid $8.5 billion surplus in 2007 to an $89 million surplus 
in 2008. Inflation has continued to fall since its peak in September 2008 and by July 2009 the

13.  The  global  crisis  and  its  impact  on  the  Philippine  economy.  Like  many  other 
developing economies, the Philippines has had to cope with the first-round effects of the turmoil 
and a crisis of confidence that has disrupted the global financial system since September 2008. 
Philippine financial markets were significantly affected by capital flight in the second half of 2008 
and the global credit crunch has made it more expensive for the Philippine public and private 
sectors to access international debt markets (Appendix 4). However, the major impact on the 
Philippine economy is the second-round effects of the collapse in global demand and its fiscal 
repercussions. The condition of the global economy deteriorated markedly in the fourth quarter 
of 2008 and new economic data on the global economy released in March 2009 confirm a much 
deeper, broader and protracted recession in several of the Philippines’ major trading partners 
not seen since World War II.  The Philippine economy contracted by 2.3% in the first quarter of 
2009 on a quarter-on-quarter basis (adjusted for seasonal effects), as external demand for 
exports plunged (Figure 1, b–d). Tourist arrivals have fallen heavily, dropping 15% at the end of 
December 2008 on a year-on-year basis. Remittances have held up much better than trade in 
goods and other services, but growth has virtually stalled with 2.9% growth in the first semester 
of 2009 compared with 15% growth for the same period in 2008. ADB staff estimate that 
remittances could fall by 2%–4% in the second half of 2009, based on the experience of the 
1997–1998 Asian financial crisis when remittances to the Philippines from overseas Filipino 
workers residing in Singapore and Hong Kong declined by an average of 7% when these two 
economies experienced recessionary conditions. 
 
14.  Against this background, the Government has revised its macroeconomic framework 
and projects growth at 0.8%–1.8% in 2009, with higher unemployment and poverty. Further 
revisions downward are expected. Development partners project a growth rate in the range of  
–1.0% to 1.0% in 2009 on the back of faltering exports, stalling foreign investments, and a 
projected drop in remittances. These projections would translate to a per capita income decline 
in the range of –3.0%  to –1.0% and a probable increase in poverty.  
 
15.  Repercussions of the crisis on fiscal policy. The global financial crisis has affected 
fiscal policy in three ways. First, the contraction in the economy means that it is necessary for 
the  Government  to  provide  a  modest  stimulus  in  2009,  while  maintaining  fiscal  discipline. 
Second, the contraction in the economy in the first quarter of 2009 has resulted in a decline in 
tax collections. As a result of the increased spending and projected decline in revenues, the 
Government projects the deficit to rise to 3.2% of GDP in 2009. Third, tight liquidity in global 
credit markets and elevated risks have raised the cost of financing the budget and refinancing 
public debt. While spreads have started to fall in recent months toward pre-crisis levels, global 
markets remain fragile and at the end of June 2009 spreads on Philippine international bonds 
increased again from an average spread of 270 bps in early June 2009 to 320 bps by the end of 
the same month (Appendix 9).

16.  Employment  losses  and  job  insecurity.  Until  mid-2008,  the  sustained  economic 
expansion was beginning to improve the Philippines' stubbornly high unemployment rate for the 
first time in a decade. Lower long-term economic growth coupled with relatively restrictive labor 
regulations meant longer-term unemployment in the Philippines was higher than in its regional 
neighbors. In 2007, the unemployment rate fell to an average of 7.3% from 7.9% in 2006. The 
latest data for April 2009 indicate an increase in the average unemployment rate to 7.6%. The 
Government is deeply concerned that the current global financial crisis will reverse its efforts to 
reduce unemployment and therefore poverty and that it will lead to a significant reduction in 
economic growth, retrenchments, domestic employment opportunities, and returns of overseas 
Filipino workers made redundant in recession-hit countries. Recent retrenchment data from the 
Department of Labor and Employment point to tens of thousands of layoffs, particularly in export 
industries and urban centers. An ADB household survey in February 2009 reported elevated 
feelings of job insecurity among workers with 20% of employed workers feeling they may not be 
in their current job within the next 12 months, of which one-fifth of these workers (or 4% of total 
workers surveyed) expect to lose their jobs because of the performance of the economy (Figure 
2).17 Sixty percent of employed workers expect it to be more difficult to find a new or better job in 
2009 than in 2008. The initial impact of job and income losses will probably occur in the major 
urban  industrial  centers  and  among  the  nonpoor  and  near-poor  since  wage  workers  are 
concentrated among these groups of households. However, multiplier effects and a potential fall 
in remittances mean the impacts of the crisis will be broader and the incidence of poverty and its 
severity will rise.  
 
17.  Government’s policy response. The Government's response has been twofold. First, it 
took a number of preemptive measures to increase liquidity in the domestic bank system, 
providing depositors with assurance and strengthening the BSP's lender of last resort facility. 
Second, it provided a modest fiscal stimulus in the national government budget for 2009 (para. 
16). In the financial sector, the key measures include the following: (i) the BSP strengthened its 
lender of last resort facility by increasing its budget for the peso rediscounting facility from 
P20 billion to P40 billion on 14 November 2008, and opened a dollar repo facility on 20 October 
2008 to ensure dollar liquidity with the banks’ dollar-denominated Philippine sovereign bonds as 
underlying collateral; (ii) the BSP increased liquidity in the banking system by easing monetary

B.  Issues and Opportunities  
1.  Fiscal Sustainability and Macroeconomic Stability 
18.  Fiscal program. In mid-2008, the Government decided, and its development partners 
concurred, that the balanced budget target date should be pushed back to 2010 to provide 
flexibility in fiscal policy in 2008 and 2009 for programs to mitigate the impact of increases in 
food prices on the poor and to maintain priority spending programs if the economy slowed down. 
The Government targeted a deficit of no more than 1% of GDP in 2008, 0.5% in 2009, and a 
balanced  budget  in  2010.  However,  with  the  severe  contraction  in  global  demand  since 
September 2008 and the recognition by the Government and its development partners that a 
larger fiscal expansion is needed, the Government has revised its medium-term fiscal program. 
It plans an increase in the national government budget deficit to 3.2% of GDP in 2009, 2% in 
2010, and a balanced budget by 2013. The 2009 national government budget deficit translates 
to  an  actual  fiscal  expansion  of  up  to  2.3%  of  GDP  over  2008  levels,18 low  by  regional 
standards.19 It covers less than one-half of the expected negative output gap in 2009 (i.e., the 
gap between potential and actual economic growth, Figure 3). In the current global environment, 
the Government faces challenges to its fiscal program in both the short and medium terms. In 
the short term, the Government needs to ensure that its fiscal expansion in 2009 provides an 
effective stimulus to the economy. This will mean ensuring that the stimulus is timely, well 
targeted, temporary, and transparent. In this regard, a key challenge will be to maintain critical 
public  spending  and  to  speed  up  disbursements  for  infrastructure  spending  in  the  key 
procurement agencies. Measures should focus on lifting the relatively low absorptive capacity 
rates  of  key  spending  agencies,  better  cash  management,  advancing  the  infrastructure 
procurement process, and scaling up targeted social assistance and employment programs. 
With tax collections falling in the first quarter of 2009, the added challenge for the Government 
will be to ensure predictability in its gross financing needs for 2009. In the medium term, the 
Government needs to ensure it sustains revenue sustainability to fund priority programs and 
longer-term debt sustainability. The crisis also provides an opportunity for the Government to 
revisit its balanced budget objective and to explore the feasibility of alternative fiscal rules that 
could anchor fiscal policy (Appendix 4).

grew by 11.0% in 2008 over 2007 levels. BIR cash collection was up 9.0% in 2008, short of its

on  tobacco  products  were  also  better  by  18.8%.  Value-added  collections  under  the  BIR's 
jurisdiction fell by 3.2% over 2007 levels. Poor compliance with value-added tax (VAT) appears 
to occur in the services sector, especially in retail and trade, which comprise a large number of 
smaller taxpayers. Continued weak tax administration and inefficiencies in the tax policy indicate 
that the BIR has been unable to lift VAT collections through improvements in tax efficiency and 
enforcement. The prevalence of VAT exemptions (resulting in breaks in the VAT chain and 
thereby  weaker  self-compliance),  and  generous  taxable  income  deductions  in  the  growth 
sectors of the economy continue to limit growth-induced tax collection. In the first semester of 
2009, tax collection fell by 5.2% over levels in the same period in 2008, reflecting the economic 
contraction in the Philippines. Customs collections fell 8.3% (VAT on imported goods fell 12.9%) 
and the BIR's collections fell by 5.1% on a year-on-year basis. ADB assessments indicate that 
tax revenues in the Philippines have historically exhibited a systematic, moderate procyclical 
pattern, i.e., during periods of fast economic growth direct and indirect taxes grow faster than 
nominal GDP, and during sharp slowdowns, taxes fall faster than nominal GDP. ADB estimates

20.  Sustaining priority spending. The Government is targeting an increase in the rate of 
noninterest expenditure to GDP from 12.2% in 2006 to 14% by 2010. Ensuring priority spending 
is sustainable within the budget framework over the medium term will require further effort to 
raise tax revenues. This remains a long-term challenge for the Government. Its approach is 
threefold: (i) to implement its tax administration reforms; (ii) to enhance and institutionalize the 
anticorruption initiatives in the BIR and the BOC; and (iii) to improve tax policies. The BIR has a 
comprehensive tax administration reform program up to 2010, but implementation has been 
delayed  and  is  proceeding  more  slowly  than  initially  expected.  This  is  partly  due  to  the 
complexity of the reform program and the fact that the BIR’s budgetary resources for long-term 
reforms have been critically constrained. Staff resistance, vested interests, and corruption have 
also contributed to the slow start to reform as it is rolled out to the regional tax offices. The 
Government must address longer-term resource constraints at the BIR, including raising its 
personnel budget. Gradual and incremental reforms have been made to tax administration. A 
draft bill has been submitted to Congress to allow the BIR to set salaries for its staff closer to 
market values. Through the 2009 national government  budget, the DBM has allocated an 
additional P1.0 billion in funds to the BIR to hire up to 3,000 new technical staff nationwide. The 
BIR has made it a priority to institutionalize its anticorruption revenue program, Run After Tax 
Evaders (RATE), as lessons from subprogram 2 of the DPSP indicate that it is necessary to 
institutionalize these initiatives within the agencies to ensure they are sustainable and constitute 
an effective deterrent to tax evasion. ADB is providing TA to the BIR, the Department of Finance 
(DOF), and the Department of Justice to strengthen revenue-enhancing measures, enforcement, 
and prosecution of tax evaders. 
 
21.  Several tax policies have weaknesses in design and structure that limit tax revenue 
growth. Under the 2005 amendments to excise tax legislation, the DOF has been delegated 
authority to raise specific taxes until 2011. It raised excise tax on tobacco and alcohol in 2007 
and again in January 2009. However, the excise tax legislation has too many bands that allow

13
producers to minimize tax liabilities and it is not indexed to inflation. At the end of 2007, the DOF 
submitted to Congress a revised investment incentives bill. Deliberations have progressed in 
Congress but have recently slowed with the upcoming presidential elections next year. The 
Government will need to issue implementing rules and regulations to rationalize investment 
incentives  once  Congress  passes  the  bill.  However,  tax  exemption  legislation  initiated  by 
Congress has also eroded the tax base.   
 
22.  Debt management. Improvements made in public debt management since 2005 have 
resulted in significant fiscal savings. Overall, debt interest costs in the national government 
budget have fallen from 36.7% of total national government revenues in 2005 to 22.6% in 2008, 
freeing up substantial resources for priority programs. This was partly because of specific debt 
management measures, such as lengthening the average maturity of government debt to 7.1 
years and maintaining a diverse portfolio of obligations within a disciplined fiscal program. 
Nevertheless, public debt at 56.0% of GDP and debt servicing costs (interest and amortization) 
at about 8.0% of GDP are relatively high by developing country standards. Much needs to be 
done to improve the institutional framework for debt management. Debt management systems 
at the DOF are compartmentalized with separate units in the Bureau of Treasury, Corporate 
Affairs (covering contingent liabilities of government-owned and controlled corporations and 
others), and the International Finance Group (covering official development assistance and 
international  commercial  borrowings).  Monitoring  of  contingent  liabilities  under  the  Build–
operate–transfer law is done through the National Economic and Development Authority (NEDA) 
investment coordination committee (ICC). Consequently, debt management is not conducted 
within an integrated debt framework as suggested by best international practice. A medium-term 
debt management and risk strategy and policies are needed.  
 
2.  Governance in Public Financial Management  
23.  Public  financial  management.  Implementing  improved  systems  for  public  financial 
management,  including  the  medium-term  expenditure  framework  (MTEF),  and  aligning  the 
budget planning process with strategic objectives and priorities is integral to improving public 
financial  management  efficiency,  and  therefore  sustainable  priority  spending.  Progress 
continues to be made. The DBM continues to increase the use of the MTEF in preparing the 
2009 and 2010 budgets, including preparing budget strategy papers and disseminating forward 
estimates for 3 years with the increasing involvement of all 22 departments in formulating the 
forward estimates. In 2007, the organizational performance indicator framework (OPIF) that 
links budget allocations to management performance indicators was rolled out to all national 
government line departments, four constitutional offices, and state colleges and universities. 
The  DBM  has  started  to  pilot  internal  control  systems  in  selected  line  ministries.  The 
Government, ADB, and other development partners have identified several core areas to be 
addressed, beginning with budget preparation through to budget execution and reporting, which 
will require a much longer-term, coordinated effort in capacity development (paras. 24–28).  
  
24.  Budget preparation and credibility. A multiyear perspective in fiscal planning and 
budgeting needs to be strengthened. Key to this is completing the rollout of the MTEF to line 
ministries and continuing to involve them in computing the forward estimates needed to ensure 
the MTEF is institutionalized within the Government. While much progress has been made in 
this area, more needs to be done. In particular, currently the DBM sets forward estimates at a 
disaggregated level of spending, which tends to create rigidities in resource allocation within a 
department. Over the longer term, the DBM should set the forward estimates for the budget of 
the department and provide the department with flexibility to determine resource allocation 
across priorities. Often in-year reallocations of the approved budget between line agencies

14    
 
undermine the credibility of the budget composition, defined as the extent to which the budget is 
realistic and is implemented as intended. Public access to key fiscal information in the budget 
documents  needs  to  be  improved,  including  presentation  of  budget  documents  for  public 
consumption. Finally, revenue forecasts for budget preparation are often ambitious, in part 
because  of  weaknesses  in  forecasting capabilities  at  DOF  and  its  revenue  agencies.  The 
budget presentation is not accompanied by debt risk and sustainability assessments. 
 
25.  Budget  execution  and  controls.  There  are  weaknesses  in  the  recording  and 
management of cash balances, as having more than one treasury account makes reconciling 
balances difficult. The monthly (and even daily) cash forecasting capabilities of the Bureau of 
Treasury need to be strengthened to improve the predictability of the availability of funds for 
expenditures  during  the  budget  cycle.  The  DBM  retains  excessive  controls  over  spending 
commitments and cash disbursements and the practice of quarterly cash releases (instead of 
semiannual) elevates the unpredictability of funding and leads to excessive agency “savings” at 
the end of the year. The central departments have limited authority over the spending agencies 
under them. Current reporting arrangements make it difficult to reconcile the budget allocation 
releases  and  the  actual  expenditures  incurred  by  agencies  because  of  differences  in  the 
accounting formats used by the DBM and the chart of accounts used by the Commission of 
Audit (COA).

27.  Internal controls system. Internal control and audit systems in spending agencies are 
an  essential  element  of  budget  execution  and  financial  reporting.  Internal  control  provides 
reasonable assurance that the systems, rules, and procedures of the organization will help 
achieve efficiency of operations, reliability in financial reporting, and compliance with applicable 
regulations.  Internal  audit  is  an  independent,  objective  activity  designed  to  add  value  and 
improve  an  organization’s  operations.  There  are  weaknesses  in  payroll  controls,  internal 
controls for nonsalary expenditures, and the lack of independent internal audits within line 
ministries. Until recently, there were no generic guidelines for internal control systems for line 
agencies to follow and not all agencies have established independent internal audit units.  
 
28.  Budget accounting, recording, and reporting. Accounts reconciliation and in-year 
budget reports on obligations, cash releases and allotments, obligations, and disbursements are 
not  done  on  time,  and  thus  do  not  track  progress  against  indicators  of  budget  efficiency 
effectively.  The  key  underlying  cause  of  weaknesses  in  budget  execution,  recording,  and 
reporting is the absence of an integrated government financial management information system 
(GFMIS). The current manual recording of accounts payable results in frequent reporting delays 
from line ministries and regions to DBM. The Government is developing the initial components 
of a GFMIS, including the eBudget (electronic releasing and programming of the budget), 
eNGAS (electronic national accounting system), and PhilGEPS (electronic procurement system), 
but these are fragmented and, except for the PhilGEPS, coverage is low. The Government pilot-
tested the e-Budget system in the first quarter of 2008 before the rollout to regional offices. It will 
be important for key agencies of COA, DBM, and DOF to establish a consensus on the way 
forward for integrating the fragmented GFMIS. This will require a formal coordinated effort by 
key government agencies with longer-term support from development partners. The DBM has 
undertaken a study of government financial information systems and has begun consultations 
with departments and stakeholders on ways to integrate them. Completing the design and 
development of the GFMIS over the medium term will be important to enhance the efficiency 
and effectiveness of services and to improve transparency. ADB technical assistance is being 
provided to the DBM to support it to develop a GFMIS road map with clear targets. Monitoring 
this reform is included in the post-program monitoring framework (para. 51). 
 
3.  Investment Climate 
29.  Investment  growth.  The  investment  expansion  that  began  in  2007  continued 
throughout  the  first  half  of  2008  with  private  construction  growing  by  20%  and  durable 
equipment and machinery expanding by 6% on a year-on-year basis. Total fixed investment 
slowed to 4.3% in the second half of the year. Overall, the investment–GDP ratio has increased 
from 14.0% of GDP in 2006 to 15.0% in 2008. Private investment has stagnated in 2009. The 
Government has increased public spending on infrastructure this year and this should lift the 
investment rate. However, ADB staff estimates suggest the Philippines is underinvesting by as 
much 5 percentage points of GDP and much needs to be done to put it on a sustainable growth 
path, such as improving the business regulatory climate, trade facilitation, and establishing a 
transparent public–private infrastructure investment policy framework.

permit approval process, thereby creating an arms-length and more transparent process in 
clearance. It has been piloting this national single window at the port of Batangas since March 
2009 and the single window needs to be rolled out to all major ports.  
 
4.  Enhance Human Capital and Social Inclusion 
34.  In the current global environment, the Government faces both short- and long-term 
challenges to its poverty reduction efforts. In the short term, the Government's priority is to 
mitigate the worst effects of the current global economic crisis on the poor. In the long term, it is 
to make progress on the MDGs and to expand coverage of targeted programs to the poor.  
 
35.  Poverty impacts in the short term. The incidence of poverty is expected to rise in 2009. 
The transition will initially be through job losses and reduced incomes in the industrial urban 
centers, and is expected to spill over to the rural areas as the slowdown becomes more broadly 
based. The expected slowdown in overseas deployment of Filipino workers will put pressure on 
the labor market. Remittances are expected to fall, which will have an impact on poverty.

response mechanism that can provide information about developments in household poverty 
sufficiently quickly to allow it to respond promptly with targeted poverty alleviation programs. To

priorities are to make progress on the MDGs and to expand coverage of social protection 
programs to the poor.  Fiscal austerity measures introduced from 2001 to 2006 to reduce the 
Government deficit disproportionately hurt social policy expenditures. This is one of the reasons 
the Philippines is having difficulty in meeting some of its MDG targets, particularly those in 
education and health. The Government is well aware of these problems and is committed to

declines in performance. The Government has been addressing resource constraints through 
substantial increases in real spending in the social sectors since 2007 (Figure 7). At the same 
time, the Government has drafted proposals for a new needs-based formula for allocating 
school funding on a more equitable basis. In the health sector, the Government continues to 
make progress on its "Fourmula One for Health" implementation framework for health sector 
reforms in the medium term (2005–2010), including implementing its MTEF for better resource 
allocation  within  the  health  sector.  The  overall  goal  is  to  improve  the  quality,  efficiency, 
effectiveness, and equity of the health system, particularly for the poor. ADB's Health Sector 
Development Program offers one example of how systematic provincial public expenditure 
reviews and the use of programmatic initiatives can help effect improvements to local service 
delivery. 24 
 
39.  The  Government  has  a  wide  range  of  social  protection  programs,  including  health 
insurance,  education  scholarships  for  the  poor,  school  feeding  programs,  subsidized  rice 
through  the  National  Food  Authority,  public  employment  programs  and  the  community 
development program known as the Kalahi program. However, these are fragmented and the 
overall results in terms of net welfare to recipient groups are mixed. An ADB study on social 
protection coverage shows that such programs only cover one-third of the poor compared with 
an average of one-half of the poor in Southeast Asia and East Asia. The Government is looking 
at ways to enhance social protection coverage of the poor. Under subprogram 2, the National 
Economic  and  Development  Authority  (NEDA)  issued  Social  Development  Committee 
Resolution No. 1 on adopting a Philippine definition of social protection. With the aim of refining 
targeted programs under the new definition, the DSWD is implementing the CCT program, and 
the Department of Labor and Employment (DOLE) and relevant agencies are implementing 
CLEEP.  
 
C.  Lessons 
40.  In the process of assessing implementation progress on the triggers for subprogram 3 
(Appendix 6), several lessons were identified and used to formulate subprogram 3.  
(i)  The Government's fiscal consolidation since 2005 has given it the fiscal space it 
needs to respond to the current crisis and to expand its deficit to 3.2% in 2009. 
(ii)  The  program  cluster  approach  with  triggers  contains  sufficient  flexibility  to 
respond  to  lessons  identified  during  implementation  and  to  incorporate  new 
government policy priorities, such as measures to mitigate the economic impact 
of the current crisis and to protect critical public expenditure (para. 56). 
(iii)  Subprogram 3 is the final subprogram of the program cluster, but it is essential 
that policy dialogue and engagement should continue during the period leading 
up to the formation of a new government after the presidential election in May 
2010.  The  program  cluster  approach  provides  a  post-program  monitoring 
framework (para. 66 and Appendix 2, Policy Matrix). Ongoing TA support on tax 
administration,  public  financial  management,  and  the  investment  climate  will 
continue during the post-program monitoring period.  
 
41.  As a result, subprogram 3 incorporates several important new policy features to support 
the Government’s efforts to mitigate the adverse impact of the global crisis on macroeconomic 
stability and poverty.

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
42.  The impact of the subprogram 3 will be to restore the Philippines' economic expansion to 
its long-term path and to lower unemployment. The outcome of subprogram 3 will be greater 
investment, achieved through a set of program outputs to improve fiscal sustainability (through 
lower budget deficits, greater tax efforts, and better public debt management); enhance public 
financial management (through better reporting mechanisms, more efficient and transparent 
procurement systems, and stronger anticorruption programs in the revenue agencies); make the 
investment  climate  more  attractive  (through  lower  business  transaction  costs  and  better 
coordination of public–private participation in infrastructure); and strengthen human capital and 
social inclusion (through better poverty targeting and monitoring of assistance).  
 
43.  The DPSP cluster includes a series of policy reforms that underpin the key priorities of 
the Government’s reform agenda. Subprogram 3 also includes a series of policy measures that 
address  the  increased  vulnerabilities  and  risks  to  the  Philippine  economy  from  the  global 
financial crisis and the sharp slowdown in the global economy. These reforms are designed to:  
(i)  improve  fiscal  sustainability,  maintain  macroeconomic  stability,  and  improve 
creditworthiness by enhancing the quality of fiscal management by (a) increasing 
tax revenues for 2008–2009 through tax policy reforms; (b) strengthening tax 
administration and enforcement, and reducing revenue leaks through improved 
governance;  (c)  reducing  inefficient  spending  to  permit  increased  social  and 
poverty-related spending; (d) strengthening the debt management strategy to 
manage  government  contingent  liabilities  and  risks  prudently  and  (e)  giving 
depositors' confidence in the domestic banking system; 
(ii)  enhance  public  financial  management    governance  by  (a)  improving  public 
financial management  from budget preparation through to budget execution, 
accounting,  recording,  and  reporting;  (b)  strengthening  performance 
management and improving public service delivery; (c) reforming procurement; 
(d)  implementing  anticorruption  and  enforcement  strategies  for  revenue-
collecting agencies and key procurement agencies; and (e) sustaining critical 
public expenditures while maintaining budget discipline to mitigate the poverty 
impacts of the deceleration in growth; 
(iii)  improve  the  investment  climate  and  promote  rural  development  by  
(a)  clarifying  and  strengthening  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for 
investments and trade, (b) facilitating infrastructure development through greater 
public–private  participation  and  greater  coordination  of  public  infrastructure 
investments, and (c) improving rural–urban connectivity; and  
(iv)  enhance human capital and social inclusion by improving the policy framework 
for social protection, sustaining real spending on health and education, improving 
targeting of programs, improving service delivery, piloting the CCT program tied 
to  performance  outcomes  in  child  education  and  health,  refining  public 
employment  programs,  and  establishing  a  national  poverty  monitoring  and 
response  system  to  help  mitigate  the  impact  of  the  economic  slowdown  on 
poverty. 
 
B.  Policy Framework and Actions 
 
44.  The  report  and  recommendation  of  the  President  for  subprogram  2  of  the  DPSP 
identified  13  policy  triggers  for  subprogram  3  (footnote  1).  In  the  process  of  assessing

21
implementation progress, the Government proposed three additional triggers and measures 
aimed at addressing the increased vulnerabilities and risks to the Philippine economy from the 
global financial crisis and the sharp slowdown in progress on poverty reduction (Appendix 6 
provides an assessment of subprogram 3 triggers): 
(i)  Increase in bank deposit insurance. The Government is making every effort to 
maintain macroeconomic stability in the current adverse global financial turmoil. 
One  lesson  from  the  1997–1998  financial  crisis  was  that  the  absence  of  a 
credible deposit insurance scheme can exacerbate the loss of confidence in the 
banking sector and lead to a run on the banks. The Government has therefore 
increased the ceiling for deposit insurance from P250,000 to P500,000. 
(ii)  Speed up budget disbursements. Based on experience, disbursement rates for 
public spending are relatively low in the first quarter of each fiscal year (75%–
80% at key spending agencies). The procurement process is also slow to start as 
line agencies do not begin until allotments (giving the authority to obligate) are 
released by the DBM. The Government has therefore proposed a new trigger on 
actions  to  speed  up  disbursements  and  advance  procurement  without 
undermining recent gains in procurement governance. 
(iii)  Establish poverty monitoring and reporting mechanism. The Government 
has recommended adding a new trigger on establishing a poverty monitoring and 
reporting  system  mechanism.  It  is  concerned  about  the  need  for  a  prompt 
response  to  increased  poverty  as  a  result  of  the  crisis.    The  focus  of  this 
initiative—to measure poverty impacts—will be on collecting real-time data on 
employment  and  dismissals,  wage  data,  farmers’  incomes,  prices  of  basic 
commodities, health, education, and social welfare.  
 
45.  In total, the Government and ADB are focusing on 16 policy triggers (Appendix 2, policy 
matrix). Most are supported by 17 measures to outline a blueprint for government implementing 
agencies to follow and execute, while a few measures have clear outputs (e.g., establish a unit, 
produce an action plan, or carry out capacity building and training programs). The Government 
has made substantial progress in completing these measures. Of the 16 triggers, it has fully or 
substantially accomplished 13. One has been partially accomplished, and implementation of the 
remaining two is ongoing. The Government is committed to completing these two remaining 
triggers during the post-program monitoring period. All of the 17 other supporting (nontrigger) 
measures have been completed.  
 
46.  Progress toward the DPSP performance indicators and targets set out in the design and 
monitoring framework for subprogram 1 and updated for subprogram 3 (Appendix 1, column 3) 
has been substantial, although the global financial crisis has set back progress on some of the 
targets.  Of  the  25  performance  indicators  and  targets,  four  have  been  achieved:  (i)  two 
sovereign credit upgrades by Standard & Poor’s since 2006, (ii) a consolidated public sector 
budget surplus since 2006, (iii) computerization of revenue district offices under the BIR's tax 
administration program, and (iv) rollout of the OPIF to national agencies and four constitutional 
bodies. Twelve are on track to achieve medium-term targets, four have slowed, four have 
regressed from their medium-term paths or baselines, and the remaining indictor is a new one. 
Progress  on  the  following  indicators  has  slowed  or  regressed:  economic  growth,  the 
unemployment rate, and fixed capital investment (primarily due to the global financial crisis and 
recession), tax collections as a share of GDP, and elementary school enrollments and survival 
cohort rates. The national government balanced budget target has been delayed from 2009 to 
2013 as a consequence of the global crisis.

agenda  on  a  continuing  basis  rather  than  through  predetermined  rigid  conditions,  the

1.  Accomplishments under Subprogram 3 
48.  Subprogram 3 focuses on four of the seven core policy areas outlined by the Philippines 
Development Forum (PDF): (i) improve fiscal sustainability, maintain macroeconomic stability, 
and improve creditworthiness; (ii) improve governance in public financial management and 
reduce  corruption;  (iii)  strengthen  the  investment  climate  and  rural  development;  and  (iv) 
enhance human capital and social inclusion.  
 
a.  Improve Fiscal Sustainability, Maintain Macroeconomic Stability, 
and Improve Creditworthiness 
49.  Fiscal discipline. The Government’s immediate objectives are to protect critical public 
spending within a disciplined fiscal framework and to reduce nonfinancial public sector debt to 
65% of GDP by 2010. In 2008, (i) the national government deficit came in at 0.9% of GDP, the 
third  consecutive  year  it  has  been  below  1%,  and  a  consolidated  public  sector  surplus 
surpassed program expectations; and (ii) nonfinancial sector public debt fell from 87% of GDP 
in 2005 to 60% in 2008, and is on track to return to debt levels of the early 1990s. The national 
government debt decreased from 72% in 2005 to 56% by the end of 2008. 
 
50.  Tax revenue sustainability. Tax revenues increased by 11% in 2008. Major gains were 
achieved in corporate income tax collection (18%) and tobacco excise (19%). VAT collections 
fell by 3% in 2008 due to weak compliance in the services sector. During subprogram 3 the 
Government  initiated  medium-term  actions  to  improve  revenue  sustainability,  including  
raising the excise tax rate in January 2009 in line with existing legislation. The DOF has 
submitted a bill to Congress to reform excise taxes, including indexing specific rates to inflation 
and reducing the number of tax bands to two. While tax administration reforms were slow to 
begin,  some  progress  has  been  made:  (i)  the  BIR,  with  assistance  from  USAID  and  the 
Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC), computerized 71 revenue district offices (97% of the 
uncomputerized offices) so that tax information can be provided online to the central office in 
Manila; (ii) the backlog of tax registrations and returns has been reduced, with 348,465 tax 
registrations and 1,235,889 income tax returns encoded and filed with assistance from the 
USAID and MCC grant; and (iii) some progress was made in validating about 47% of the 
unregistered corporations (about 9,429 registered at the Securities and Exchange Commission) 
and inactive taxpayers in the database (162,352 taxpayers) identified under subprogram 2. The 
revenue district offices are continuing to validate the identified taxpayers. 
 
51.  Debt management. In June 2009, the DOF issued a department order establishing a 
debt and risk management division (DRMD). The DRMD will oversee debt policy and strategy, 
carry out analysis, produce debt indicators, and undertake debt sustainability assessments. The

23
department order was issued subject to the DBM's approval of the DOF's rationalization plan, 
which is expected later in 2009. Implementation of the order is ongoing and is included in the 
post-program monitoring framework (para. 66). ADB technical assistance will be provided to 
support capacity development of the DRMD (Appendix 8). Monitoring of contingent liabilities in 
public–private infrastructure projects will be shifted from the investment coordination committee 
(ICC) to the DRMD. With assistance from AusAID, the DOF updated the contingent liabilities 
related  to  public–private  partnerships  in  infrastructure  under  the  BOT  Law.  It  also  made 
recommendations on monitoring contingent liabilities and submitted them to the ICC.  
 
52.  Deposit insurance. The Government introduced preemptive measures to protect the 
economy. A key measure under subprogram 3 was raising the deposit insurance to P500,000 to 
boost depositors' confidence in the domestic banking system and to bring the ceiling into line 
with those in neighboring countries.  
 
53.  Impact  and  outcomes  of  subprogram  3. By the end of 2009, it is expected that 
subprogram 3 will have helped to stabilize macroeconomic fundamentals and to prepare the 
economy for a return to growth. The fiscal consolidation from 2005 to 2008 was a major 
achievement and created fiscal space for the Government to mitigate some of the impacts on 
the economy and poverty in 2009 and 2010 arising from the global financial crisis. Fiscal 
sustainability will be maintained, as reflected in the country's sustainable debt levels and the 
Government's medium-term fiscal program, which targets lower budget deficits for 2011 and 
2012.  
 
b.  Enhance Governance in Public Financial Management and Reduce 
Corruption 
54.  Medium-term expenditure framework. The DBM continues to make gradual progress 
in  improving  the  budget  preparation  process  and  transparency  in  budget  execution.  The 
Government’s  immediate  objectives  are  to  implement  the  MTEF  and  OPIF,  improve 
transparency in budget planning and execution, and strengthen internal control systems based 
on good international practice. The DBM continued to refine and expand the medium-term 
expenditure  framework  (MTEF)  for  the  2009  budget  and  the  2010  budget  preparations.  It 
updated and produced forward estimates for a 3-year rolling period for all 22 line ministries and 
attached agencies and issued these as indicative budget ceilings for the 2010 budget. The 
Government also continued to strengthen public sector performance management through more 
aggressive  implementation  of  the  performance-based  budgeting  process  by  the  DBM  and 
completing the adoption of the OPIF. The DBM completed the rollout of the OPIF to four 
constitutional  offices—(i)  Civil  Service  Commission,  (ii)  Commission  on  Elections, 
(iii) Commission on Audit (COA), and (iv) the Office of the Ombudsman (OMB)—and state 
universities and colleges for the 2009 budget. 
 
55.  Transparency in budget execution. The DBM has made gradual progress in improving 
transparency in the budget through the following key measures in 2008 and 2009. First, a key 
underlying cause of weaknesses in budget execution, recording, and reporting is the absence of 
an integrated government financial management information system (GFMIS). The Government 
has taken initial steps toward achieving consensus among stakeholders on the design and 
development of an integrated GFMIS and the DBM, with assistance from the US Trade and 
Development Agency, has completed a study of the scope and requirements of an integrated 
GFMIS. Second, the Government has begun reforms to strengthen internal control and internal 
audit within government agencies. Guidelines for internal control systems have been printed for 
dissemination  to  agencies,  GOCCs,  and  LGUs.  The  DBM,  with  technical  assistance  from

24    
 
AusAID, started piloting the internal control systems guidelines in two key spending agencies 
(DPWH and DepEd) in the fourth quarter of 2008. ADB and AusAID will support the piloting of 
internal control systems in an additional set of agencies in 2009. 
 
56.  Measures  to  sustain  critical  public  spending.  Subprogram  3  supports  the 
Government’s efforts to mitigate the impact of the global financial crisis on poverty. The DBM 
has implemented a number of measures to expedite budget disbursements, including (i) the 
issuance of a DBM circular letter25 shifting cash releases to a 6-month cash release basis and 
requiring line ministries to spend each month’s cash allocation or lose it; (ii) a Government 
Procurement Policy Board (GPPB) circular to line ministries clarified that ministries can start the 
procurement process before receiving allotments from DBM (authority to obligate the budget) 
but the signing of contracts will require receipt of these allotments. 
 
57.  Procurement. The following measures were undertaken in 2008 and 2009 to improve 
transparency and efficiency in public procurement. First, PhilGEPS, the electronic procurement 
system, completed its second year of full operation and major progress was made in increasing 
compliance with the 2003 law on procurement. By the end of 2008, all 12 GPPB member 
agencies were posting bid opportunities and award notices, compared with nine in 2007. The 
GPPB made also progress in expanding outreach to non-GPPB members with the Department 
of Agriculture, the DSWD, the DENR, and the BIR all posting bid notices and awards on 
PhilGEPS in 2008. ADB TA is helping to enhance PhilGEPS outreach to agencies and civil 
society organizations.26 Second, the Procurement Transparency Group, with the Government 
and major civil society organizations (CSOs) as members, began operations under subprogram 
3. The group began tracking the procurement of selected infrastructure projects from the time 
the bid notice is posted to selection of the winning bid. 27 Regular updates on procurement 
monitoring are posted on the group’s website.28 If discrepancies are identified in the bid and 
awards process, the group notifies the bids and awards committee and stakeholders to resolve 
any transparency concerns that may arise. Third, to enhance transparency, the group issued 
implementing guidelines pursuant to its authority under Presidential Executive Order 662 (which 
established the group under subprogram 2). The guidelines require all government agencies to 
post annual procurement plans, procurement monitoring reports on activities specified in the 
annual procurement plans, and blacklisting and delisting orders on the GPPB website.   
 
58.  Expenditure  integrity.  Subprogram  3  supports  the  Government’s  efforts  to  reduce 
revenue leakage by institutionalizing its anticorruption and collusion initiatives within agencies. 
Examples include the Run After Tax Evaders (RATE) program at the BIR and the Run After the 
Smugglers (RATS) program at the BOC. In July 2009 the DBM approved BIR's rationalization 
plan to transform the Enforcement Service to an Enforcement and Advocacy Service (EAS) 
under the Legal Division—a major achievement in strengthening enforcement capabilities at the 
BIR. The EAS has four divisions, one of which, the Special Prosecution Division (SPD), handles 
prosecution of RATE cases. The SPD will have 23 positions, and it is intended that most of the 
litigation lawyers initially assigned to the RATE program with MCC assistance will be transferred

60.  Impact and outcomes of subprogram 3. By the end of 2009, the DPSP is expected to 
have  improved  the  budget  allocation  of  resources  and  to  have  linked  the  medium-term

MTEF). More departments will have an MTEF, and the rollout of the OPIF to four constitutional

c.  Improve the Investment Climate  
61.  Investment climate reforms. The Government’s main objective is to increase the share 
of investment and infrastructure spending in GDP. Critical reform areas under the DPSP include 
(i)  clarifying  and  strengthening  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  investments, 
(ii) improving trade facilitation, (iii) facilitating infrastructure development, and (iv) promoting 
rural  development  through  a  better  investment  climate.  Subprogram  3  supports  the 
Government’s efforts to reduce business transaction costs in 2008 and 2009. A memorandum 
order was submitted to the President's Office for approval in July 2009. This mandates NEDA to 
begin advocating the regulatory impact assessment (RIA) and to develop an action plan for its 
institutionalization. The DTI has continued improvements in business registration by developing 
the first phase of the Philippine business registry for sole proprietors online. Phase 2 covering 
partnerships and corporations involving the Securities Exchange Commission is expected to 
begin in 2009. The Government and members of the PDF held a strategic agribusiness planning 
workshop  in  March  2009.  This  discussed  the  formulation  of  a  strategic  agribusiness 
development  plan  and  the  bottlenecks  in  agriculture,  including  production,  post-production, 
marketing  and  distribution  and  financing sectors.  A  first draft  of  the  strategic  agribusiness 
development plan has subsequently been drafted. 
 
62.  Trade facilitation and infrastructure policy. To enhance transparency and lower trade 
facilitation costs, the Bureau of Customs worked with 21 agencies that issue import permits to 
put in place a national single window. The "e2m Customs Systems Project", of which the 
national single window is a component, has been piloted at the port of Batangas and the BOC 
has also implemented an import assessment system under the e2m Customs Systems Project. 
The Government has submitted to the Senate for concurrence the instrument of accession to

26    
 
the Revised Kyoto Convention, which would promote greater transparency and efficiency in 
customs facilitation. In infrastructure policy, the medium-term objective is to establish a public–
private infrastructure partnership project preparation facility. In the interim, the Government 
issued a set of guidelines to govern joint ventures between government and private sector 
entities;  it  is  currently  drafting  a  set  of  standard  transaction  documents  for  public–private 
partnerships; and preparing options for a strategy for the Government’s risk assessment and 
management, particularly for infrastructure projects approved by the investment coordination 
committee (ICC). 
 
63.  Impact and outcomes of subprogram 3. By the end of 2009, the DPSP-supported 
program is expected to have improved the Philippine investment climate. The investment–GDP 
ratio is expected to have increased from 14% of GDP in 2006 to 15% by 2009 and the share of 
public investment in GDP to have increased by 1–2 percentage points. This progress will be 
achieved by reducing the transaction costs of doing business (as reflected in reduced number of 
days to start up a business). 
 
d.  Enhance Human Capital and Social Inclusion 
64.  The  DPSP  supports  the  Government’s  agenda  to  improve  the  social  sectors  by 
increasing funding, improving governance in the budget process and procurement, engaging 
civil society in monitoring procurement, and improving targeting of poverty reduction programs. 
In 2008, the DSWD scaled up the CCT program to cover 337,345 households. Each receives 
P1,400 per month per household based on conditions related to child education and health, and 
prenatal and post-natal health care for pregnant women. The technical committee on poverty 
statistics of the National Statistical Coordination Board (under NEDA) produced a draft poverty 
monitoring mechanism to provide timely data and assessments of the impact of the economic 
slowdown and other external shocks on the poor that would allow the authorities to respond 
promptly. The NSCB is expected to approve it in the third quarter of 2009 and implementation 
will follow. To mitigate some of the worst effects of the crisis on the poor, Presidential Executive 
Order 782 earmarked 1.5% of ministries' maintenance expenditure for new hiring of displaced 
workers accredited with DOLE on temporary contracts of up to 6 months.  
 
65.   Impact and outcomes of subprogram 3. By the end of 2009, the DPSP will have 
improved systems for poverty monitoring and reporting. The CCT program has been scaled up 
to 337,345 families, potentially making a significant dent in poverty.

C.  Financing Plan 
 
67.  The Government has requested a loan of $250,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources to finance subprogram 3. The loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace period 
of 3 years, an interest rate determined in accordance with ADB's London interbank-offered rate 
(LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  set  forth  in  the  draft 
program loan agreement presented to the Board. The Government has provided ADB with 
(i) the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility on the basis 
of  these  terms  and  conditions,  and  (ii)  an  undertaking  that  these  choices  were  its  own 
independent decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
68.  The ADB funds are to support reforms outlined in the development policy letter and 
policy matrix (Appendix 2). The loan size was determined by the strength of the policy package, 
its  development  impact,  the  importance  of  the  sectors  covered,  adjustment  costs,  direct 
budgetary costs, and the development financing needs of the Government, as estimated by the 
DOF. The direct budgetary costs of subprogram 3 include, for example, (i) increasing the 
personnel budget at BIR (P1 billion in 2009 to address resource constraints at the agency) and 
(ii)  helping  to  meet  the  costs  of  implementing  public  financial  management  initiatives  and 
institutionalizing the anticorruption programs at the revenue agencies, the BIR and BOC, among 
other reforms.

(Table 3). In addition to supporting the Government’s efforts to balance the national government

development and social spending in 2009 and, given the need for additional funding to mitigate

1.  Program Management

3.  Procurement and Disbursement  
 
72.  The program loan of $250 million will be released in a single tranche upon satisfactory 
completion of all conditions in the subprogram 3 policy matrix (Appendix 2). The loan proceeds 
will be used to finance the full foreign exchange costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of items 
produced  and  procured  in  ADB  member  countries  no  more  than  180  days  before  the 
effectiveness date of the loan. Items specified in the list of ineligible items (Appendix 7) and 
imports financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources are excluded. In accordance with the 
provisions of ADB’s Simplification of Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for 
Program Loans (1998), the loan proceeds will be disbursed to the Republic of the Philippines as 
the Borrower. No supporting import documentation will be required if during each year that loan 
proceeds are expected to be disbursed, the value of Philippine total imports minus imports from 
nonmember countries, ineligible imports, and imports financed under other official development 
assistance is equal to or greater than the amount of the loan expected to be disbursed during 
such year. The Government will certify its compliance with this formula with each withdrawal 
request.  Otherwise,  import  documentation  under  existing  procedures  will  be  required. 
Disbursements will be made under the simplified procedures for program loans. In accordance 
with the simplified disbursement procedures and related requirements for program loans, all 
goods and services produced and originating in ADB member countries will be procured, with 
due consideration to economy and efficiency, in accordance with the Government’s standard 
public procedures and normal private sector commercial practices acceptable to ADB. Goods 
commonly traded on the international commodity market will be procured in accordance with 
procedures appropriate to the trade and acceptable to ADB.  
 
73.  The  reform  needs  supported  under  the  DPSP  will  be  financed  by  local  currency 
counterpart funds generated from the proceeds of the subprogram 3 loan.  
 
4.  Anticorruption and Fiduciary Issues 
74.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the Government. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and 
transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged 
corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the Program. To support these 
efforts, relevant provisions of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the loan regulations 
and the bidding documents for the Program. In particular, all contracts financed by ADB in 
connection with the Program shall include provisions specifying the right of ADB to audit and
