examine the records and accounts of the Executing Agency and all contractors, suppliers, 
consultants, and other service providers as they relate to the Program. 
 
75.  A  core  component  of  the  DPSP  cluster  focuses  on  governance  and  reduction  of 
corruption in key national government agencies vulnerable to such practices. The DPSP cluster 
includes reforms to public financial management through the MTEF, and measures to improve 
transparency and accountability in the budget cycle in agencies with large procurement budgets 
(e.g.,  DepEd,  the  Department  of  Agriculture,  DOH,  and  DPWH).  The  DPSP  supports 
implementation of the procurement reform law and measures to improve transparency in the 
procurement  process  (para.  75).  The  DPSP  supports  institutionalizing  the  anticorruption 
programs of RATE and RATS within their agencies to ensure their longer-term sustainability 
(paras. 57–58).  
 
76.  The country’s financial management systems were assessed before subprogram 1 in 
2007 so ADB could better understand the fiduciary risks and determine the appropriate fiduciary 
arrangements for the DPSP. This assessment was updated for subprograms 2 and 3. The 
update is based on diagnostic work done in the last 12 months including the public expenditure 
and financial accountability assessment led by the World Bank, with ADB participation during 
the first stage. The assessment identified core areas to be addressed with development partner 
support.  Discussions  with  the  Government  during  implementation  of  the  public  financial 
management  triggers  under  subprogram  3  and  its  ongoing  reforms  to  public  financial 
management were also considered. Based on this assessment, the fiduciary arrangements 
proposed for the DPSP remain acceptable. The assessment indicates that the Government has 
made  progress  in  improving  systems  related  to  public  financial  management,  financial 
accountability,  and  procurement,  although  weaknesses  remain  and  continued  progress  on 
implementing  the  Government’s  program  to  improve  governance  and  reduce  corruption  is 
essential. The Government places significant emphasis on making progress in implementing the 
MTEF in line ministries and the OPIF; improving the credibility of the budget, its execution, and 
reporting; and the rollout of internal control systems and internal audit. In this regard, the ADB 
policy  and  advisory  TA  is  designed  to  support  the  DBM  to  strengthen  public  financial 
management capacity.

V.  TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
80.  In connection with subprogram 3, an advisory technical assistance grant is proposed. 
This is the second of three TA projects for public financial management envisaged over the next 
3  years  to  continue  ADB's  engagement  in  public  financial  management  reforms  in  the 
Philippines. The three TA projects are designed to strengthen capacity at the DBM and line 
ministries to implement public financial management reforms. The first TA project is providing 
support to advance GFMIS dialogue, advisory assistance on budget execution, and piloting the 
ICS laying the foundations for subsequent TA. The second TA project will support the DBM, the 
Bureau of Treasury, and the DOF to implement and monitor key public financial management 
reforms. The TA will cover capacity development support for the newly established debt and risk 
management  division,  the  rollout  of  an  internal  controls  system  at  the  national  level,  and 
continued support to the design and development of the GFMIS, among other activities. Its 
measures will be agreed as part of the post-program monitoring framework. The third TA project 
will build on activities under the second TA project, including the integrated GFMIS, the rollout of 
internal control systems, debt management, and cash revenue forecasting. The second TA 
project is estimated to cost $1,150,000 equivalent, of which ADB will provide $800,000, to be 
financed  by  the  ADB’s  TA  funding  program  (TASF—other  sources).  The  Government  will 
provide the remaining $350,000 in kind by providing counterpart staff and other facilities. A team 
of international and national consultants will implement the TA. ADB will engage a combination 
of a consulting firm and individuals in accordance with Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time). The firm will be engaged following quality- and cost-
based selection (80:20 quality–cost ratio) using a simplified technical proposal. A total of 51 
person-months of consulting services will be required (18 international and 33 national). The TA 
is expected to commence in the first quarter of 2010 and to be completed by the fourth quarter 
of 2011. The TA purpose, outputs, methodology, implementation arrangements, and budget are 
in Appendix 8, and the terms of reference for consultants are in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
VI.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Expected Impacts 
 
81.  The key benefits expected from the DPSP are as follows: 
(i)  Progress toward medium-term fiscal sustainability will promote macroeconomic 
stability  and  foster  broad-based  economic  growth,  job  creation,  and  poverty 
reduction, all of which are cornerstones of the Government’s MTPDP and PDF.  
(ii)  Better public financial management governance will improve prioritization and 
efficiency of spending in key sectors such as the social sectors.

32    
 
(iii)  Lower transaction costs for business, because of the reduction in bureaucracy, 
will open new opportunities; increase investment, productivity, and incomes; and 
create jobs. 
(iv)  Higher  infrastructure  spending  will  generate  long-term  growth,  stimulate 
investment, create jobs, and raise incomes. 
(v)  Increased  spending,  better  targeted  social  assistance  programs,  and 
implementation of the CCT program will improve social sector outcomes. The 
expansion of the CCT program will have potential gender benefits for maternal 
health and girls' education: (i) pregnant women will receive pre- and postnatal 
care beginning in the first trimester of pregnancy, and the birth will be attended 
by  a  skilled  health  professional;  (ii)  parents  will  attend  parent  effectiveness 
service classes; (iii) children aged 0–5 will receive regular preventive health 
checkups and vaccines; (iv) children aged 3–5 will attend day care or preschool 
programs; and (v) children aged 6–14 will be enrolled in school and demonstrate 
at least an 85% attendance rate at school. The Government is intending to begin 
benchmarking data in third quarter of 2009 to assess program performance. 
(vi)  The institutionalization of governance programs including the MTEF, regulatory 
impact assessments and the anticorruption initiatives in the BIR and the BOC will 
improve the sustainability of key governance programs. 
 
B.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
82.  The DPSP is subject to the following risks: 
(i)  The global financial crisis has hurt the Philippines. The major impact on the 
economy has been the second-round effects of the decline in global demand and 
its fiscal repercussions. The economic slowdown in the Philippines and the risk of 
a decline in remittances will feed into higher poverty in 2009. However, the 
impact on poverty will be partly offset through the scaling up of the CCT program 
and an increase in infrastructure development in 2009 and 2010. 
(ii)  With the economic stresses in 2009 and an election in 2010, the Government 
and or members of Congress may be tempted to introduce populist policies that 
could  threaten  fiscal  discipline  in  2010.  However,  the  Government  has 
announced its budget target for 2010 at 2% of GDP and since 2006 it has 
demonstrated  commitment  to  meeting  its  fiscal  targets.  The  post-program 
framework will ensure dialogue is continued with the Government on fiscal policy.  
(iii)  The 2010 presidential elections may slow implementation of reforms. However, 
the  Government  has  full  ownership  of  the  DPSP  reform  program,  which  is 
embedded  in  the  Philippines  Development  Forum  and  its  sector  strategies. 
Moreover, the Government, ADB, and the Government of Japan have agreed to 
a post-DPSP program monitoring framework to maintain progress on reforms.  
(iv)  Weak  capacity  in  some  of  the  crucial  spending  agencies  (such  as  the 
Department of Agriculture) may limit the effectiveness of the Government's fiscal 
stimulus in 2009 and the long-term delivery of services. Longer-term institutional 
reforms may be needed in some agencies.

Our macroeconomic policy response to the external shocks has been both appropriate and 
responsive. Earlier in 2008, the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) shifted to a tighter monetary 
position to counter possible second round inflationary effects from the commodity price surge. 
Then in the fourth quarter it shifted to an expansionary position to ensure sufficient liquidity in 
the banking system against rapidly falling inflation. By May 2009 inflation had fallen to 3.3% well 
within the BPS's inflation target for 2009. To boost confidence in the financial sector, the 
Government  took  a  number  of  preemptive  measures  aimed  at  increasing  liquidity  in  the 
domestic bank system, assuring confidence of depositors, and strengthening the central bank's 
lender of last resort facility.  
 
With these preemptive measures in place, the macroeconomy stabilized and key indicators 
showed encouraging signs of improvement. Commercial bank lending continued robust growth 
at about 20% in the first quarter of 2009 on a year-on-year basis; the stock market and the peso 
have stabilized since November and yields on domestic bonds have recently fallen back to pre-
crisis levels, Gross international reserves continued to accumulate in 2009, equivalent to 6.3 
months of import cover and three times greater than external debt maturing this year, providing 
a sufficient buffer against further moderate external shocks. Spreads on Philippine sovereign 
dollar bonds have also declined in recent months but still remain above pre-crisis levels.  
 
The global crisis has impacted on our fiscal situation, although this remains manageable as a 
result of successful implementation of our fiscal consolidation strategy since 2004. Our fiscal 
consolidation efforts brought down the non-financial sector public debt from over 100% of GDP 
in 2003 to 61 % at the end of 2008 back to levels last seen in the early 1990s. Perhaps one of 
the most important achievements of the fiscal consolidation program has been the creation of 
fiscal space to mitigate some of the poverty impacts from the global crisis in 2009. In particular, 
the program has resulted in an increased share of discretionary spending from 26 % of total

 SECTOR ANALYSIS: MACROECONOMIC ASSESSMENT AND DEBT SUSTAINABILITY 
ASSESSMENT 
 
1.  The sector analysis assesses recent macroeconomic developments and identifies the 
issues  and  threats  faced  by  the  Government  in  achieving  its  medium-term  development 
objectives  of  fiscal  sustainability,  macroeconomic  performance,  and  poverty  reduction.  The 
immediate pressing issues for macroeconomic policy are the deceleration in economic growth 
and its fiscal repercussions. The critical issues for the Government in the short term are to 
sustain critical public spending and to address additional financing needs arising from the 
decline in tax revenues in the first quarter of 2009. Over the medium term, the Government 
priorities include sustaining priority spending by raising revenues, improving the efficiency of 
public expenditure management, and increasing the effectiveness of debt management. The 
Government has outlined a revised fiscal sustainability strategy with medium-term balanced 
budget targets. While the balanced budget target has served the Philippines well over the last 4 
years, the current crisis has provided an opportunity to revisit the policy of balancing the budget 
target and explore alternative fiscal rules that could anchor fiscal policy and operations in the 
future.   
 
A.   Economic Growth and Inflation 
 
2.  Economic growth was 4.6% in 2008, lower than the 7.3% in 2007, but above the regional 
average. The slower economic growth was a combination of a contraction in public spending in 
the first quarter of 2008, a surge in domestic inflation that reduced domestic consumption from 
6% in 2007 to 4.6% in 2008, and the recession in the United States that lowered demand for 
Philippines  exports.  Private  investment  continued  to  expand  in  the  first  half  of  2008,  with 
purchases of durable equipment expanding by 6% on a year-on-year basis, among the highest 
rates for a decade, and private construction expanding by 20% for 2008. As the global crisis has 
intensified since September 2008 and global demand has contracted, investment and trade has 
slowed.  In  the  first  quarter  of  2009,  the  economy  decelerated  sharply  to  contract  by  an 
annualized 2.3% (seasonally adjusted) as exports plunged and consumption stalled. Economic 
growth for 2009 is projected to be in the range of 0.8%–1.8%. This translates to a negative 
output gap of 4%–5% of GDP (Figure A4.1). Indicative of a sharp cyclical downturn in the 
economy is the rapid fall in core inflation, which reached 3.3% in July 2009, down from its peak 
of 8.0% in November 2008 and the fall in tax collection of 5.2% in the first semester of 2009.

1.  Fiscal Crisis and Consolidation 
5.  Fiscal  consolidation  from  2004  to  2007.  Fiscal  indiscipline,  coupled  with  poor 
monetary policy management until 1993 when the central bank was reformed, were the main 
contributors to macroeconomic instability from the late 1970s to 2004. In 2005, the Philippines 
emerged from a period of serious fiscal difficulty. From 1998 to 2004, budget revenues dropped, 
which significantly suppressed expenditure in the social sectors, leading to a substantial decline 
in public sector real wages.1 The deficit reached 5.2% of GDP and the nonfinance public sector 
debt exceeded 100% of GDP in 2004. The high and unsustainable deficits triggered bouts of 
peso exchange rate instability. The Government has restored macroeconomic stability and 
maintained  it  through  fiscal  discipline.  The  cornerstone  and  the  measure  with  the  highest 
revenue impact was the reform of value-added tax in November 2005, which extended the 
value-added tax base to energy products, and increased the rate from 10% to 12% effective 
February 2006. Other measures included increasing (i) excise taxes on alcohol and tobacco 
products by 30% at the end of 2004 (increased again in January 2007 and January 2009, 
although not fully indexed to inflation), (ii) the corporate income tax rate from 32% to 35% 
(which reverted to 30% in January 2009 as mandated in the amendments to tax legislation), and 
(iii)  electricity  tariffs.  As  a  consequence  of  these  reforms,  tax  revenues  grew  by  over  1.3 
percentage points of GDP in 2006, the national government deficit fell to 0.9% of GDP from 
2.7% in 2005, and the consolidated public sector budget turned in a surplus for the first time in 
almost a decade, aided by the improvement in the finances of the National Power Corporation. 
Fiscal consolidation continued in 2007 with the national government deficit falling to 0.2% of 
GDP and the consolidated public sector budget remaining in surplus for a second consecutive 
year.  
 
6.  Increased social expenditures. The fiscal crisis and subsequent consolidation program 
suppressed  expenditures  in  the  social  sectors  and  in  infrastructure.  However,  by  2006 
substantial resources were freed for priority spending in the 2007–2009 budgets. In particular, 
discretionary  spending  in  the  national  government  budget  increased  from  26%  of  total 
expenditures  in  2006  to  37%  in  2008  with  the  social  sectors  and  infrastructure  the  main 
beneficiaries (Figure A4.3). The Government has provided substantial real increases in social 
spending with the Department of Health (DOH) budget doubled in 2009 compared with its 2006 
levels; the Department of Education (DepEd) budget up by 42% in real terms over the same 
period; and the Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) budget up by 300% in 
real terms over the same period.

2.  Global Financial Crisis and Fiscal Expansion 
7.  Fiscal  policy  behavior  over  the  economic  cycle. In the past, fiscal policy in the 
Philippines has not been effective in mitigating the effects of economic downturns. This is partly 
a characteristic of most developing economies, as fiscal policy usually does not have embedded 
in it automatic stabilizers on the expenditure side of the national government budget that would 
allow for effective countercyclical spending. In the Philippines, relatively high public debt and 
large nondiscretionary commitments (interest payments and transfers to local government units) 
in  the  budget  limited  the  opportunity  for  discretionary  countercyclical  spending.  The  fiscal 
consolidation program that has been in carried out since 2004 suppressed primary expenditures. 
The national government budget does have modest automatic stabilizers on the revenue side 
but these are generally offset by the expenditure side so that the overall national primary budget 
balance appears to be generally neutral to economic downturns. Figure A4.4 presents trends in 
the Philippines' fiscal policy behavior over the economic cycle (as measured by the output gap). 
It shows the percentage point changes in tax revenues to GDP since 1991 mapped against the 
economic cycle. As is apparent from the figures, tax revenues tend to be moderately procyclical, 
i.e., tax collections grow more quickly than nominal GDP during higher growth periods (implying 
an increase in the tax ratio) and drop more quickly than nominal GDP during economic troughs 
(implying a fall in the tax ratio). Indirect taxes (excluding customs duties) levied on goods and 
services and direct income taxes generally move together over the economic cycle, although 
changes in direct income taxes tend to carry over into the next year as the tax code permits 
corporations to carry over losses to the succeeding fiscal year. The large drop in tax collections 
in the first 4 months of 2009 is consistent with this cyclical pattern. Tax (cash) collections from 
the Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR) fell 6.5% on a year-on-year basis.2 Customs collection 
(duties and VAT on imported goods) from the Bureau of Customs (BOC) fell 12% for the same 4 
months on a year-on-year basis as imports plummeted. The 13% drop in VAT collection on 
imported goods was the major contributor to the fall in customs revenue during this period.

3.  Medium-Term Fiscal Policy Issues 
 
9.  Considerable fiscal gains have been achieved since 2005, and fiscal space has been 
provided from increased tax revenues. Building on these is an important medium-term goal. In 
the context of the current crisis and the Government's medium-term budget framework, the four 
major medium-term issues are: (i) exploring alternative fiscal rules to balance the budget, 
(ii) sustaining priority spending by increasing revenues, (iii) improving the efficiency of public 
expenditure management, and (iv) better debt management practices. 
 
10.  Alternative  fiscal  rules. While the Government's fiscal policy and its medium-term 
target of a balanced budget has served the Philippines very well in achieving consolidation, the 
global crisis has provided an opportunity to explore with stakeholders alternative fiscal rules. As 
discussed in paras. 8–9, in the past fiscal policy has not been effective in mitigating the effects 
of the economic cycle. In fact budget expenditures have at times exhibited a procyclical pattern. 
Moreover, because of external shocks to the economy, the balanced budget target has been 
changed three times since 2005, potentially undermining its credibility. An increasing number of 
countries  have  adopted  fiscal  rules  to  anchor  fiscal  policy  and  these  rules  are  generally 
formalized through legislation such as fiscal responsibility acts. Rules may pertain to debt, 
budget balances (overall or primary), expenditures, or some combination of these.3 For example, 
Thailand does not set budget ceilings but anchors fiscal policy in debt rules set in legislation and 
Ministry of Finance policy guidelines for public debt. It may also be feasible to anchor fiscal 
policy to public debt rules in the Philippines. The post-program monitoring framework includes a 
measure to assess fiscal policy and explores the feasibility of formalizing fiscal rules.  
 
11.  Sustaining priority spending. The Government’s goal is to raise national government 
noninterest expenditures by an additional 1 percentage point of GDP over the next 2 years 
(excluding countercyclical spending in 2009). To achieve this goal, the Government targets an 
increase in tax revenues to 15%. The tax revenue target is achievable over the medium term 
but requires greater efforts. Revenue management is challenged by (i) the proliferation of tax 
incentives in growth sectors of the economy that may have resulted in as much as P47 billion in 
foregone revenues; (ii) generous income tax deductions that have eroded the tax base; (iii) a 
poorly structured excise tax regime; and (iv) weak tax administration, including administering 
value added tax and modernizing business procedures and systems of revenue district offices 
(RDOs). The Government is systematically addressing these issues. The Bureau of Internal 
Revenue (BIR) has a comprehensive tax administration reform program to 2010 with support 
from the World Bank, Swedish International Development Agency, and ADB (in 2008), but 
implementation has been slower than expected. This is partly due to the complexity of the 
reform program and its outreach to all RDOs, but it is also because the BIR lacks resources. 
Nevertheless, progress has been made. The Government has allocated an additional P1.0 
billion to its personnel budget and this could potentially increase staffing by 25%. Ninety-seven 
percent of all uncomputerized RDOs have now been computerized and the backlog of tax 
registrations and returns has been reduced, with over 350,000 tax registrations and 1.2 million 
in income return files encoded into the electronic system. The Government has also submitted 
draft bills to Congress on amending excise tax legislation (submitted in 2008) and consolidating 
investment incentives (submitted at the end of 2007) to improve revenue sustainability.  Over 
the longer term, the Government will need to continue to address budget resource allocations to 
the BIR as it implements its tax reforms and enhances tax administration in monitoring tax 
credits, managing tax arrears, tax audits, and anticorruption programs. Tax exemptions initiated 
by Congress have eroded the tax base in recent years.

Progress is being made. The Department of Budget and Management (DBM) has incorporated

longer-term, coordinated effort, and a platform approach to capacity development.  
 
13.  Debt sustainability. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) undertook an Article IV 
Consultation with the Philippines in November 2008 (footnote 2). As part of its consultations, the 
IMF undertook a debt sustainability assessment (DSA) based on different economic growth, 
interest rate, primary budget balance, and exchange rate shocks. The IMF updated its DSA for 
the purposes of the DPSP 3. This appendix summarizes the pertinent findings of the DSA. 
 
14.  The Philippines' public sector debt is broadly sustainable, but short-term risks have 
increased due to global financial instability. Public debt as a share of GDP has declined to ratios 
last seen in the early 1990s, but remains high by regional standards. At the end of 2008, 
national government public debt amounted to 56% of GDP, down from its peak of 83% in 2003 
(Figure A3). Nonfinancial public sector (NFPS) debt declined to 59.9% from 101.0% during the 
same period (Figure A3). A prudent borrowing strategy, including lengthening the average 
maturity of debt to 7.1 years and moving to domestic financing;4 fiscal discipline (operating 
primary budget surpluses); and sustained economic growth contributed to the rapid decline. 
Debt servicing costs as a share of national government budget revenues also declined from 
36.7% in 2005 to 22.6% in 2007, thereby freeing up substantial resources for priority spending 
since 2007. However, at 8% of GDP, the Philippines’ public debt servicing costs (amortization 
and interest payments) are high by regional standards.

A.  Introduction 
 
1.  To support implementation of the Development Policy Support Program (DPSP), the 
Government of the Philippines requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide policy 
and advisory technical assistance (TA). This TA is the second of a series of three TA projects to 
support the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) and Department of Finance (Debt 
and  Risk  Management  Division,  DRMD)  and  Bureau  of  Treasury  in  implementing  and 
monitoring  key  public  financial  management  reforms  with  a  focus  on  enhancing  cash 
management, budget execution, accounting, recording, and reporting and to strengthen debt 
management systems. The first TA project laid out the building blocks for developing an action 
plan and implementation timeframe for an integrated government financial management system 
(GFMIS), provided assistance for the piloting of an internal control system, and other related 
areas in budget execution. The second TA project builds on the GFMIS and focuses on the 
implementing budget execution reforms needed for an integrated GFMIS, assistance for better 
cash revenue forecasting; capacity development support for the newly established debt and risk 
management division; and a rollout of internal control system at the national level. All supporting 
measures have been agreed as part of the post-program monitoring framework. The third TA 
project will build on activities under the second TA project, including an integrated GFMIS, 
rollout  of  internal  control  systems,  debt  management  and  cash  revenue  forecasting.  It  is 
intended that at the end of the series of TA projects, the DBM will be in a position to have a 
long-term public financial management reform strategy and to fund the implementation of an 
integrated  GFMIS  (Figure  A8).  The  scope  of  the  TA  parallels  the  DPSP,  covering  the 
governance and public financial management component, and impact and outcomes listed in 
the design and monitoring framework in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Issues 
 
2.  Medium-term  sustainable  priority  spending  requires  more  efficient  public  financial 
management. The key challenges for the Government are to strengthen cash management 
practices at the Bureau of Treasury, balance the public expenditure program between capital 
spending and recurrent expenditures, as well as between discretionary and nondiscretionary 
spending  items  (local  government  unit  transfers,  wages,  and  interest  payments);  and  to 
implement  improved  public  financial  management  systems,  including  those  on  debt 
management. The key public financial management issues were comprehensively discussed in 
the main text of the RRP (paras. 22–28). This section briefly notes the key issues that are or will 
be addressed by the three TA projects.  
 
3.  Debt management. The debt management systems at the DOF are fragmented, with 
separate units at the Bureau of Treasury, Corporate Affairs (covering contingent liabilities of 
government-owned  and  controlled  corporations  and  others),  and  the  International  Finance 
Group  (covering  official  development  assistance  and  international  commercial  borrowings). 
Monitoring of contingent liabilities under the build–operate–transfer law is done through the 
NEDA  Infrastructure  Coordination  Committee.  Consequently,  debt  management  is  not 
conducted within an integrated debt framework as suggested by best international practice. 
There is no integrated debt management strategy and debt sustainability assessments do not 
accompany the proposed budget plan. The software is outdated, although the DOF does plan to 
upgrade its system. Under subprogram 3, the DOF approved the establishment of the DRMD, 
which will function as a middle office to undertake public debt policy formulation and analysis. 
Capacity development of the division requires longer-term support in the form of staff training

and policy advisory assistance to develop a debt management strategy and to carry out public 
debt  analysis  and  a  bi-semester  debt  sustainability  assessment.  Under  the  post-program 
monitoring  framework,  it  is  anticipated  that  the  DRMD  will  formulate  a  debt  management 
strategy in 2010. The second TA project will support this effort. 
 
4.  Budget execution and controls. There are several gaps in budget execution that need 
to be addressed in the short and long terms. These include weaknesses in recording and 
management of cash balances, as more than one treasury account makes reconciling balances 
difficult. The monthly (and even daily) cash forecasting capabilities of the Bureau of Treasury 
are limited and are not integrated with the revenue forecasts made by the BIR. Current reporting 
arrangements  make  it  difficult  to  reconcile  the  budget  allocation  releases  and  actual 
expenditures incurred by agencies because of differences in accounting formats used by the 
DBM and the chart of accounts used by the Commission of Audit (COA). 
 
5.  Internal controls system. Development of internal control and internal audit systems in 
spending agencies is an essential element of budget execution and financial reporting. There 
are weaknesses in payroll controls and internal controls for nonsalary expenditures and a lack 
of  independent,  internal  audits  within  line  ministries.  Until  recently,  there  have  been  no 
guidelines for internal control systems for line agencies to follow and not all agencies have 
established independent internal audit units. With assistance from the Australian Agency for 
International Development (AusAID), the DBM has produced internal control guidelines and 
piloted  them  in  two  ministries.  ADB  supporting  two  additional  pilots  at  the  Department  of 
Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) and the Department of Labor and Employment 
(DOLE). The Government intends to complete the rollout of internal control systems to national 
agencies over the next 3 years.  
 
6.  Budget accounting, recording, and reporting.  Accounts reconciliation, in-year budget 
reports on obligations, cash releases and allotments, obligations, and disbursements are not 
done on time, and thus do not allow effective tracking of budget efficiency indicators. The key 
underlying cause of weaknesses in budget execution, recording, and reporting is the absence of 
an  integrated  government  financial  management  information  system  (GFMIS).  The  current 
manual recording of accounts payable results in frequent reporting delays from line ministries 
and regions to the DBM. With assistance from the US Trade and Development Agency, the 
Government has completed an analysis of the GFMIS at the DBM and line ministries, and 
provided a tentative costing of rolling out an integrated GFMIS nationally.  The DBM has also 
begun consultations with stakeholders and development partners on a strategy for the future. It 
is important for the key agencies—COA, DBM and DOF—to establish a consensus on a way 
forward for integrating the fragmented GFMIS. This will require a formal coordinated effort by 
key government agencies, with longer- term support from development partners. ADB technical 
assistance is being provided to the DBM to support it in developing a GFMIS road map with 
clear targets and monitoring. This reform is included in the post-program monitoring framework.

  3.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,150,000 equivalent. ADB will provide a $800,000 grant 
financed by the Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources). The Government will 
provide the remaining $350,000 in kind by providing counterpart staff and facilities (Table A8). 
 
4.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The DBM will be the executing agency, as it is responsible for national budget execution. 
The DOF will be an implementing agency. The DBM chairs the interagency task force on 
development of an integrated GFMIS, with the COA and the DOF as members. The DBM will 
provide office space, counterpart staff, and other services to the consultants and it will closely 
coordinate  with  line  ministries  and  agencies  and  other  stakeholders  involved  in  TA 
implementation. The TA will begin in the first quarter of 2010 and be completed in the third 
quarter of 2011. The equipment and software will be procured in accordance with the ADB 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) and the Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook.5 The equipment and software will be handed over to the DBM and the 
DRMD upon completion of the TA.  
 
16.  A team of international and national consultants will implement the TA. ADB will engage 
a combination of a consulting firm and individuals in accordance with the Guidelines on Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). The firm will be engaged following quality- 
and cost-based selection (80:20 quality–cost ratio) using a simplified technical proposal. A total 
of 51 person-months of consulting services will be required (18 international and 33 national).  
 
17.  The consultants will provide regular written reports in English: (i) an inception report, 
including a comprehensive implementation plan, will be submitted within 4 weeks after the TA 
starts; (ii) an interim report; (iii) progress reports; and (iv) a draft final report and, subsequently, 
a final report to be submitted before the TA ends. The specific timing and content of the reports 
will be discussed with implementing agencies and submitted to them and to ADB.
